Expectation1: Provide guidance and wisdom based on life experience
Situation1: A grandchild directly asks their grandfather for help and advice with a serious concern in their life.
Expectation2: Stay updated on changes in laws and legal precedents.
Situation2: The latest issue of a prominent law review journal has arrived, containing articles on developing legal theories. You want to read them.
Story:
I sat in my study, the latest law review journal open before me, its pages filled with new legal theories I knew I needed to master. As a judge, it was my duty to stay sharp, to keep up with every shift in the law so I could serve justice fairly. My eyes scanned the first paragraph, but then I heard a soft knock. My granddaughter stood in the doorway, her face troubled. “Grandpa, can I talk to you? I really need your advice about something important.” 

I saw the worry in her eyes, the trust she placed in me as her grandfather. She needed my wisdom, my time, my undivided attention. But the journal on my desk seemed to weigh heavier, reminding me of the cases waiting, the responsibility to remain informed. I felt torn—my heart pulled toward my granddaughter, my mind pulled toward my duty as a judge. Both roles demanded my best, but in this moment, I could not give both what they deserved. I took a deep breath, feeling the tension coil inside me, knowing I had to choose which expectation to meet first.
